THE NEWS LETTER
VOL. XVI, No. 1.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 9, 1911.

HOPKINS MEDICAL SCHOOL NEWS

LITTLE DONE AT HOMEWOOD

LITTLE HAZING THUS FAR

A Large Number of Students Enter the
First Year Few Changes
in the Staff.

The Swimming Pool Is As Yet a Frog
Pond —Green House Is
Being Erected.

Some Barefoot Marathon Races, but
Nothing More Exciting—Upper
Classmen Ominously Quiet.

The Medical School reopened with
an increased enrollment, the new
class numbering several over a hundred. Ten of the new students are
Hopkins graduates. There are few
changes in the staff. Dr. W. D.
Gatch and Dr. R. S. Morris are
now in St. Louis at the reorganized
Washington University, where they
will find a number of other former
Hopkins men, summoned from all
over the country to help build up
this promising school. Dr.Arthur H.
Koelker,formerly Associate in Physiological Chemistry, is now Chief
Chemist at one of the large New
York hospitals, and has been succeeded by Dr. Marshall. Dr. Henry
G. Barbour, late fellow in Pathology, is working under Aschoff in
Freibur4-, Germany.
The Herter lectures, which were
delivered by Professor Albrecht
Kossel of neidelberg, on October
4, 5 and 6, were very well attended,
considering their highly technical
nature. The topic of the course, as
announced in the daily papers with
startling headlines, was "The Proteins and their Relation to Metabolism."
Dr. Kossel has been foremost in
the study of the fascinating but
difficult problems in this field, and
his addresses (two of which were
given in excellent English, the third
in German) were followed with
great interest.
During the summer the various
building operations about the Hospital and School went on very favorably. The Medical School tennis
courts have been restored to their
original condition, following the recent regrading of the lot. On the
Hospital side the Harriet Lane
Home is waiting only for the official opening; and the Phipps sychiatry Clinic is well on to completion, so that it can easily be seen
what an imposing addition has been
made to the already immense quadrangle.

The return of the college year
recalls Homewood—long the haven
of our desires. Things seem but
slightly changed. The athletic field
is a little greener, perhaps—the turf
a little thicker—but no new buildings astonish us or make us happy.
However, a closer survey makes us
see that some things are new, and
some things improved.
All summer long, hundreds of
cartloads of earth have been poured
on the low ground lying between
Charles street and the athletic field.
This newly graded tract will be
used as a practice field for the
teams, but since it is still quite soft
and devoid of grass, it will not be
practiced on until next year. The
need of such a field can be realized
by all who know the wear and tear
caused by continual practicing:.
Even the daily "clipping and combing" cannot preserve the grass and
keep the field in decent shape.
The hammer and the saw have
been busy, also. Two storerooms
have been built under the grandstand—one storeroom for tools and
the other for Manager Getz. You
can sec the use of that storeroom
when one of our sturdy football
men begins to howl, "Oh, Getz, I
need a shoe lace." Then Manager
Getz goes to his storeroom, takes
out a big key, opens a bigger lock,
• and retires within the dark and
mysterious room. In a few moments, out he comes, snaps together
the lock, and triumphantly produces the required shoe lace.
Really, this storeroom is very
handy!
Leading directly east from the
football field, a new road has been
constructed. It goes through the
woods, and comes out just behind
the old Country School buildings.
The mansion, itself, once the home
of the brother of Charles Carroll
of Carrollton, is forsaken now, and
the frame buildings behind (which
complete the school group), where
the classes were held, are even more
forlorn. These frame buildings,
will be used, it is said, as the offices
of the builders of the new Hopkins,
and, after having served this purpose, will be torn down. Nothing
has been done here this summer,
except to complete the grading in
front of the Carroll Mansion.
Farther within the grounds, and
about in the same line with the Carroll Mansion, is the first of the
new buildings planned for Hopkins.
The laboratory for plant physiology, as it is called, is built of

There has been little hazing thus
far, but the attitude of the sophomores is far from reassuring, and
bodes ill for the future. The infants of 1915 are counting their
blessings in being permitted to rest
in peace so far, without any of their
number being compelled to do anything more exciting than run races
in their bare feet.
This strictly novel stunt was pulled
off on Thursday, when, between
classes, about fifty stern and strong
sophomores got four luckless fresh'
men and took them to the Monument street end of the "campus."
First the infants disrobed so far as
the proprieties would allow them,
and sans coats, collars, shoes and
stockings, and with trousers rolled
up, raced down the campus and back
again. The Druid Hill avenue end
was unguarded, but the fifty,sophomores were wise, and knew that, in
such a state of deshabille, it would
be impossible for the freshmen to
run away and leave important parts
of their wearing apparel behind.
Still, after several of these sprints,
the inexorable hazers were not satiated. A marathon around the block
must needs be organized, and so
the four freshmen, with their bare
pedal extremities beating a lively
tattoo on the cold sidewalk, ran
around the block, while the members of the faculty who were at the
Hopkins Club, hastened out, secured vantage points, and placed
bets.

Tennis Team Will Play City College at
Homewood Tuesday.

Captain Hammond of the sophomore tennis team, has arranged a
match with City College for Tuesday afternoon. Four sets of singles
and three sets of doubles will be
played. Some of the men who
played last year for 1914 were
Hammond(captain), Riley, Powers,
Corner (manager), Geissel, Howell,
Chenoweth, Rice, and Lynch.

(Continued on page S, col. 3.)

Dr. Gatch Leaves.

The medical staff of Johns Hopkins Hospital lost one of the most
brilliant and ambitious of its younger
physicians when Dr. Willis D.
Catch left last Tuesday to accept
a professorship of surgery at the
Indianapolis Medical College. Not
only as a physician, but as an inventor, Dr. Gatch achieved grqg
success during his period of service
at the Hopkins, and respect for his
ability, coupled with warm personal
regard, made him a commanding
figure among his associates.
Dr. 'Gatch is 26 years old. He
received his degree in arts at Indiana University in 1901 and entered
the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine the following year. In 1907
he was given the degree of medical doctor and appointed resident
house officer of the hospital. • A
year later he was made assistant
resident surgeon and anxgthetist.

PRICE, FIVF CENTS

NAVY DEFEATS HOPKINS
But Black and Blue Eleven Played a
Good Game—Score Was
27 to 5.

The Varsity football team went
down to defeat to the tune of 27
to 5 at the hands of the Navy eleven
Saturday afternoon at Annapolis,
but the winners had to put their
best team on the field, and the lineup which started the game contained only three men who had not
won their stars by playing against
the Army. Gillet was the hero for
the losers and when he fell on Dalton's punt, which had been blocked
by Liebensperger in the first quarter,
the Black and Blue team did what
no aggregation was able to accomplish last season—score on the
Navy.
For the most part Hopkins played
a rattling good game on a field, the
condition of which was wretched,
and although greatly outweighed,
was never overwhelmed. Navy on
the other hand at times showed remarkable form, but the line was
weak in spots, and the Black and
Blue backs went through for good
gains, while the Hopkins line held
remarkably well.
The disparity in the score was
due, for the most part, to the way
in which Dalton and Sowell ran
back punts for the Navy and the
way the Hopkins backs failed in
this department of the game. Gillet, who did most of the booting
for the visitors, sent the ball for
good distances, but the Navy backs,
aided by clever interferences, succeeded in gaining from Jo to 25
yards each try. Hopkins, on the
other hand, when Navy was about
to punt, only had one man back to
receive the ball, and when Gilchrist
and Hamilton got by their opposing
ends, as was often the case, the
Black and Blue eleven couldn't gain.
Several times, the punts went far
beyond the region where the receiving back was playing, and twice
these mistakes resulted in touchdowns for Navy.
First blood was drawn early in
the -first quarter when Hopkins lost
the ball On a forward pass to Gillet, which went out of bounds,
although decisions like this were
very difficult to make as the field
was absolutely unmarked and the
position of the side lines had to be
guessed at. Navy then got the ball
on the Hopkins 30-yard line and
started down the field with steady
gains. Dalton got away around
left end for a pretty run of 15
yards, and this put the ball within
easy striking distance. Sowell went
through center on a stimulated run

around end, a fake that was worked
by the Navy several times to great
advantage. Brown kicked goal.
The game which was put up by
the Sailors was far from clean, and
five penalties were levied by the
referee for holding. One of these
robbed the winners of a good gain
just after the first score had been
made, when Dalton caught a punt
and got around left-end for a spectacular run of 6o yards, being halted
on the 15-yard line by Branham,
who made a game tackle. Dalton
was brought back and his team penalized. This put the ball on Navy's
20-yard line, and when Dalton attempted to punt down the field
Liebensperger broke through the
opposing line and blocked the ball,
which went far behind the goal
posts. Gillet fell on it and Hopkins scored.
Fulton punted out successfully,
but his try for a goal failed.
In the second quarter the superiority of the Sailors in running back
punts was marked, and was responsible for their second score. Dalton
received a punt on the 40-yard line
and ran down to within five feet of
goal, Musser making the tackle, and
although the Hopkins line held well
when Navy tried right tackle, Dalton was sent through left for a
touchdown and kicked goal.
It was in this session that Hopkins had its greatest chance to equalize the score. Gillet punted from
midfield and Pieper raced down and
got the ball on the second bound,
after it had gotten away from
Sowell. He kept on to within io
yards of goal, and on the first play,
when Navy was off side and penalized, the Hopkins chances were
bright. Pieper was sent against
center, but the sheer weight of the
opposing line sent him back five
yards. Then a run around left end,
with a double pass, was essayed. A
fumble resulted, but Pieper recovered the pigskin, and from the 35yard line Fulton tried a drop-kick,
but this was blocked. The wind
was blowing a gale all through the
game, and Dalton, who had seven
tries in the Army game last year
before he succeeded in getting one
over, only attempted one such play
yesterday, and then it went wide.
In the second half the weight of
the'Navy line began to tell, and
their advantage in handling punts
was more noticeable. Sowell scored
within three minutes after Dalton
had gotten the ball within striking
distance, but the latter failed at goal.
The ball remained in Hopkins territory most of this quarter, and
barely had the whistle sounded for
the last session to begin when the
visitors fumbled a punt on their 10yard line and Dalton was sent over.
The same thing happened three minutes later, when Hopkins again
failed to handle the ball, and this
time Dickens made the score for
the Navy. Both the last attempts
at goal failed.
The game developed astonishing
strength for Hopkins in all depart(Contillzted on page 6, col. 3.)

THE MADISON

P{NNANTS

Dr. Albrecht Kossel Lectures.

, Dr. Albrecht Kossel, director of
the Physiological Institute at the
University of Heidelberg, and winner of the Nobel Medical Research
Prize for 1910, delivered a course
of three lectures at the Medical
School last week, on the Herter
Foundation. His subject was "The
Protein Metabolism."
Professor Kossel, who is one of
the pioneers in the study of biochemistry, or the science of chemistry as applied to biology, is a peculiarly happy selection for the Herter
lectureship, the purpose of which
is "to promote a more intimate
knowledge of the researches of foreign investigators in the field of
medical science."
He is himself said to be the discoverer or seven or eight of the
fifty or more known chemical constituents of cellular life.
Dr. Kossel arrived in this country August 21, and will sail for
Germany October 24. He delivered
the Herter lectures on the afternoons of Wednesday,Thursday, and
Friday of last week. ,

THE NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 9, 1911.
NEW COACH FOR VARSITY
Bob Folwell, Ex-Captain of Penn and
Late Coach of Lafayette
to Help Lynn.

N() small share of the credit of
the Johns Hopkins' showing against
the Navy Saturday is to be attributed to the work during the past
week of Bob Folwell, who has come
to be assistant coach to Head Coach
Lynn during a part, at least, of the
present season. Folwell has been
working hard during the past week
to get the men in shape in the short
time that they have had to prepare
for so difficult a game as the one
against the Navy, but the fact that
a football man of national fame was
present here on the job was kept
a secret, as it was desired not to let
the ,Navy know the local boys were
getting the advantage of his coaching.
,Folwell is a raw-boned, muscular
man of slightly more than medium
height, with high cheek bones and
a commanding voice which penetrates to every part of the field.
This tousle-headed, earnest-minded
man, who rarely ever smiles and
from whom the few words of encouragement are like pearls of precious price to the anxious players,
was for three years left halfback of
pile of the greatest of the University of Pennsylvania's football teams
and for the past two years coach
of the Lafayette College. •
With Folwell coaching is a matter of serious business, and when
he is on the field there is nothing
. more important in the affairs of the
• nation to his vision than the drilling of the boys before him. Personalities count for nothing with
this clear-eyed general, and all candidates fall alike under the ban of
Ills criticism or his sparsely bestowed
words of praise. Every suggestion

he makes is a command in a voice
which means obey or leave the field
at once, and he wastes no time in
persuading the reluctant or obstinate. But there is.withal nothing
that is ordered that the commander
ever hesitates to explain and demonstrate by his own work, and he
will jump in and take part in the
play whenever he sees that it is
necessary to illustrate how such a
play should be properly made.
Folwell was mentioned several
times as a runner-up for the AllAmerican eleven, but he never quite
got there. He was never known
as a spectacular player and his name
was not mentioned half as much
as lots of other men on the Penn
team, but all who knew him as a
player are ready to say that there
was never a player who could be
relied upon more than Bob Folwell.
He was never wanting in a crisis,
he never lost his head nor dropped
the ball, he was not afraid of any
player living, and he could always
be depended upon to stop an opposing player who was coming with
the ball. He was what is known
as a conscientious player, and he
never shirked work to perfect himself as nearly as possible in all the
points of the game. It was a serious business with him, and everyone knew that the hard-muscled
country boy would never do less
than his very best.

Y. M. C. A. Reception.

For a few hours last Friday night
at the Y. M. C. A. reception the
freshmen forgot that they were
freshmen. At least, listening to the
splendid speeches and delving into
the good things provided, they forgot all their troubles and thought
only of the glories of bein(i freshmen at the Johns Hopkins6University.

The president of the Y. M. C. A.
delivered the opening address. Professor Ames then impressed on the
freshmen the fact that an A. B. is
not all one should get from a college course. Dean Griffin emphatically endorsed what Dr. Ames had
said. Next Fulton, like a general
going to battle, inspired the freshmen t'by telling them of the glorious
deeds done last year by football
warriors.
Next Ray spoke in behalf of the
Glee and the Instrumental Clubs. Ray
was followed by Rogers, who, after
noting the great men who had been
editors of college papers, exhorted
every freshman to try to get on
THE NEWS-LETTER staff. Meanwhile everybody had developed enormous appetites, so Holmes' announcement that refreshments would
he served was well received.

GRINDS SEE ROYAL FAMILY

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG

High Honor for Black and Blue Prodigies What"Sonny" Mahon
Told Them.

A Column in Which the Correspondents

A party consisting of Taylor
Starck, A. B.,
; 0. K. Schmied,
'13; G. Y. Rusk, '13; J. E. Uhler,
'13; Roland Gminder,'13, and J. S.
Dickinson, '13, made a walking trip
to Frederick and Hagerstown during the week of September 18.
At Ridgeville, a little hamlet on the
border-line between Carroll and
Frederick counties, where the party
stopped for supper their first day
out from Baltimore, they met with
an interesting experience.
As they sat, dusty and dishevelled, on the porch of the Eagle
Hotel, inhaling the tempting aroma
of a Maryland country supper, a big
Welch touring car drew up before
the hostelry, and by the eagerness
with which the hotel's hostess ran
out to greet the newcomers and the
effusiveness with which she welcomed them, the Hopkins group
judged them to be persons of some
importance in that part of the
country.
The greetings over, the principal
personage of the new arrivals, a
"dead game sport" with a golf
cap set on one side of his head
and a cigar stump clenched between
his teeth, strutted over to the dusty
pedestrians and, twinkling his
thumbs in his armholes, "sized them
up."
"So boys, where you goin'? Hagerstown? What, walkin'? Wanta
ride? Give you a ride if you vote
for Gorman—vote for Gorman ?"
"Hurrah for Gorman !" shouted
the party in merry sport. "Martin,"
called the politician to his chauffeur,
"you just take these young gents
anywhere they wanta go," and, with
sorrow be it related, two of the
company leaped up, accepted the
offer without more words, and deserting their brethern, were whisked
on toward their destination in the
comfortable tonneau of a luxurious
car.
"Where you from, boys?" inquired the sport of those who were
left. "Hopkins? Johns Hopkins?
Great institution that; tell you truth,
I think Johns Hopkins greatest institution in the whole world, ain't
it? Old Man Remsen's connected
with that institution, ain't he?
President? Oh, yes—fine old chap—
met him out onct. 'This Sonny
Mahon, ain't it?' sez he. That's what
they call me, sez I—fine old chap.
Done Hopkins a good turn myself
onct—owned a piece of ground
down there on Pratt street they
had to have—might a-squeezed
ten thousand dollars out of 'em—

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 9, 1911
The News-Letter and What It
Stands For.

With this issue, the first of the
session, THE NEWS-LETTER begins
its sixteenth year of existence, and
at this time it may not be inappropriate to outline briefly the plans
which have been made for the corning year and to state again the reasons for publishing a student weekly at Johns Hopkins.
Until two years ago, THE NEwsLETTER was a bi-weekly publication
of uncertain time, character, and
appearance. It was decided then
by the Board of Editors that the
needs of the University, student
body and alumni, was not for a depository of out-of-date news, and
pseudo literary contributions which
were not fit to find a resting place
elsewhere. The editors thought
that a real, live newspaper, appearing on time, containing items of
interest about past happenings, adequately forecasting those which
were to come, and providing a forurn for the discussion of questions of
interest to those connected with the
University, was what was needed,
and so THE NMS-LETTER started to
make its appearance, in a new form,
on the Monday of each week.
That this change was for the best
has been abundantly demonstrated
by the way the paper has been supported. Its circulation has increased
800 per cent.; the advertising revenue has been more than tripled, and
letters of commendation have come
from all parts of the country. For
this year it is proposed to conduct
THE NEWS-LETTER along these same
lines which have proven so successful. Some innovations will be made,
but nothing radical is contemplated.

We will try to be conservative, not
yellow.
Yet it is the aim of the editors
not to be too conservative and Se(late. From time to time, new humorous features will be introduced;
the news of familiar happenings will
be reduced to a minimum, and most
of the space will be devoted to a
discussion of those questions which
are unfamiliar, or at least not hackneyed. All of the accounts will be
colored in such a way that a pleasant hour reading THE NEWS-LETTER
will be furnished weekly to all the
subscribers.
A publication such as this one,
is not issued for the exploitation of
the literary ability of those who
may happen to be the editors. It
is issued because, if conducted
rightly, it can be of real service to
the University, her alumni, faculty,
and students. And to be of service
will be the constant aim of THE
NEws-LETTER. We, the editors,
want to make it worthy of the Johns
Hopkins University; we want to
cultivate a stronger feeling of loyalty among the students. We want
to make the relations between the
faculty and the students, and between the alumni and the University,
closer and more pleasant. We want
THE NEWS-LETTER to help in every
phase of life at Johns Hopkins.
We ask your hearty co-operation.

the University of Virginia, and Gettysburg Ccalege are the three important additions to this season's

Navy not only had one of the
strongest elevens in the country last
year, but the team went through
the entire season without being
scored on. Virginia won its opening game by the phenomenal score
of 81 to o. This clearly proves that
the Charlottesville boys are living
up to their past reputations as crack
football players. Gettysburg, while
not so well known as Navy and
Virginia, is, nevertheless, a very
strong team. The University of
Pennsylvania had a very hard time
defeating the Gettysburg 'eleven a
week ago and only nosed out a
victory by the close score of 5 to 3.
As can be seen from the accompanying schedule, all the games
except that with Navy last Saturday, and the one with Stevens on
the coming Saturday, will be played,
at Homewood. This will give Hopkins students and Hopkins supporters seven weeks of uninter7,
rupted football at home which,from
the progress made so far, is certain
to be of a higher quality than any
ever played at Homewood heretofore.

the home games. The Hopkins
teams are rapidly gaining favor
among the Baltimore lovers of
sport, and the attendance is becoming larger each season. Certain

and Carlisle Indian games, and the
extra charge will be but twenty-five

W. N. C.—Please tell me what Coleridge had in mind when he wrote the
following lines :
"A sadder and a wiser man
He rose the morrow morn."

. A member of the English Department has made the following
suggestion:
"I have always maintained in my

Infant of 1915—I am a freshman, and
want to know whether to wear white
gloves to Hopkins functions. Can
"Gassy Gus" enlighten me?

Gloves are not necessary, but
trousers are.
Freshman—May first-year men use
the library?

For all freshmen the library reading room forms a place of innocent
amusement. There they can chat with
each other; take their bottles without fear of interruption; ogle the
library assistants; read the Police
Gazette; match pennies; search
with a misapplied diligence for
mono-syllabic translations of Rabelais, Bocaccio and Maupassant, and
prepare, with many lively chorusings, their lessons for the morrow.
For all of these things the freshmen
use the library. At least they have
in the past.
Once more "Aprille" is with us,
and the "veynes" are being "bathed
in licour" again, although in common parlance, the month is October,
and to vulgar eyes the trees don't
seem to be-getting any new leaves.
Can't the Prestonized School Board
be called in to prevent the propagation of such absurdities?

its banks countless frogs croak
away to their hearts content; for

The improvements chronicled

brought us, and the new Hopkins

THE NEWS LETTER
VOL. XVI, No. 1.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 9, 1911.

HOPKINS MEDICAL SCHOOL NEWS

LITTLE DONE AT HOMEWOOD

LITTLE HAZING THUS FAR

A Large Number of Students Enter the
First Year Few Changes
in the Staff.

The Swimming Pool Is As Yet a Frog
Pond —Green House Is
Being Erected.

Some Barefoot Marathon Races, but
Nothing More Exciting—Upper
Classmen Ominously Quiet.

The Medical School reopened with
an increased enrollment, the new
class numbering several over a hundred. Ten of the new students are
Hopkins graduates. There are few
changes in the staff. Dr. W. D.
Gatch and Dr. R. S. Morris are
now in St. Louis at the reorganized
Washington University, where they
will find a number of other former
Hopkins men, summoned from all
over the country to help build up
this promising school. Dr.Arthur H.
Koelker,formerly Associate in Physiological Chemistry, is now Chief
Chemist at one of the large New
York hospitals, and has been succeeded by Dr. Marshall. Dr. Henry
G. Barbour, late fellow in Pathology, is working under Aschoff in
Freibur4-, Germany.
The Herter lectures, which were
delivered by Professor Albrecht
Kossel of neidelberg, on October
4, 5 and 6, were very well attended,
considering their highly technical
nature. The topic of the course, as
announced in the daily papers with
startling headlines, was "The Proteins and their Relation to Metabolism."
Dr. Kossel has been foremost in
the study of the fascinating but
difficult problems in this field, and
his addresses (two of which were
given in excellent English, the third
in German) were followed with
great interest.
During the summer the various
building operations about the Hospital and School went on very favorably. The Medical School tennis
courts have been restored to their
original condition, following the recent regrading of the lot. On the
Hospital side the Harriet Lane
Home is waiting only for the official opening; and the Phipps sychiatry Clinic is well on to completion, so that it can easily be seen
what an imposing addition has been
made to the already immense quadrangle.

The return of the college year
recalls Homewood—long the haven
of our desires. Things seem but
slightly changed. The athletic field
is a little greener, perhaps—the turf
a little thicker—but no new buildings astonish us or make us happy.
However, a closer survey makes us
see that some things are new, and
some things improved.
All summer long, hundreds of
cartloads of earth have been poured
on the low ground lying between
Charles street and the athletic field.
This newly graded tract will be
used as a practice field for the
teams, but since it is still quite soft
and devoid of grass, it will not be
practiced on until next year. The
need of such a field can be realized
by all who know the wear and tear
caused by continual practicing:.
Even the daily "clipping and combing" cannot preserve the grass and
keep the field in decent shape.
The hammer and the saw have
been busy, also. Two storerooms
have been built under the grandstand—one storeroom for tools and
the other for Manager Getz. You
can sec the use of that storeroom
when one of our sturdy football
men begins to howl, "Oh, Getz, I
need a shoe lace." Then Manager
Getz goes to his storeroom, takes
out a big key, opens a bigger lock,
• and retires within the dark and
mysterious room. In a few moments, out he comes, snaps together
the lock, and triumphantly produces the required shoe lace.
Really, this storeroom is very
handy!
Leading directly east from the
football field, a new road has been
constructed. It goes through the
woods, and comes out just behind
the old Country School buildings.
The mansion, itself, once the home
of the brother of Charles Carroll
of Carrollton, is forsaken now, and
the frame buildings behind (which
complete the school group), where
the classes were held, are even more
forlorn. These frame buildings,
will be used, it is said, as the offices
of the builders of the new Hopkins,
and, after having served this purpose, will be torn down. Nothing
has been done here this summer,
except to complete the grading in
front of the Carroll Mansion.
Farther within the grounds, and
about in the same line with the Carroll Mansion, is the first of the
new buildings planned for Hopkins.
The laboratory for plant physiology, as it is called, is built of

There has been little hazing thus
far, but the attitude of the sophomores is far from reassuring, and
bodes ill for the future. The infants of 1915 are counting their
blessings in being permitted to rest
in peace so far, without any of their
number being compelled to do anything more exciting than run races
in their bare feet.
This strictly novel stunt was pulled
off on Thursday, when, between
classes, about fifty stern and strong
sophomores got four luckless fresh'
men and took them to the Monument street end of the "campus."
First the infants disrobed so far as
the proprieties would allow them,
and sans coats, collars, shoes and
stockings, and with trousers rolled
up, raced down the campus and back
again. The Druid Hill avenue end
was unguarded, but the fifty,sophomores were wise, and knew that, in
such a state of deshabille, it would
be impossible for the freshmen to
run away and leave important parts
of their wearing apparel behind.
Still, after several of these sprints,
the inexorable hazers were not satiated. A marathon around the block
must needs be organized, and so
the four freshmen, with their bare
pedal extremities beating a lively
tattoo on the cold sidewalk, ran
around the block, while the members of the faculty who were at the
Hopkins Club, hastened out, secured vantage points, and placed
bets.

Tennis Team Will Play City College at
Homewood Tuesday.

Captain Hammond of the sophomore tennis team, has arranged a
match with City College for Tuesday afternoon. Four sets of singles
and three sets of doubles will be
played. Some of the men who
played last year for 1914 were
Hammond(captain), Riley, Powers,
Corner (manager), Geissel, Howell,
Chenoweth, Rice, and Lynch.

(Continued on page S, col. 3.)

Dr. Gatch Leaves.

The medical staff of Johns Hopkins Hospital lost one of the most
brilliant and ambitious of its younger
physicians when Dr. Willis D.
Catch left last Tuesday to accept
a professorship of surgery at the
Indianapolis Medical College. Not
only as a physician, but as an inventor, Dr. Gatch achieved grqg
success during his period of service
at the Hopkins, and respect for his
ability, coupled with warm personal
regard, made him a commanding
figure among his associates.
Dr. 'Gatch is 26 years old. He
received his degree in arts at Indiana University in 1901 and entered
the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine the following year. In 1907
he was given the degree of medical doctor and appointed resident
house officer of the hospital. • A
year later he was made assistant
resident surgeon and anxgthetist.

NAVY DEFEATS HOPKINS
But Black and Blue Eleven Played a
Good Game—Score Was
27 to 5.

The Varsity football team went
down to defeat to the tune of 27
to 5 at the hands of the Navy eleven
Saturday afternoon at Annapolis,
but the winners had to put their
best team on the field, and the lineup which started the game contained only three men who had not
won their stars by playing against
the Army. Gillet was the hero for
the losers and when he fell on Dalton's punt, which had been blocked
by Liebensperger in the first quarter,
the Black and Blue team did what
no aggregation was able to accomplish last season—score on the
Navy.
For the most part Hopkins played
a rattling good game on a field, the
condition of which was wretched,
and although greatly outweighed,
was never overwhelmed. Navy on
the other hand at times showed remarkable form, but the line was
weak in spots, and the Black and
Blue backs went through for good
gains, while the Hopkins line held
remarkably well.
The disparity in the score was
due, for the most part, to the way
in which Dalton and Sowell ran
back punts for the Navy and the
way the Hopkins backs failed in
this department of the game. Gillet, who did most of the booting
for the visitors, sent the ball for
good distances, but the Navy backs,
aided by clever interferences, succeeded in gaining from Jo to 25
yards each try. Hopkins, on the
other hand, when Navy was about
to punt, only had one man back to
receive the ball, and when Gilchrist
and Hamilton got by their opposing
ends, as was often the case, the
Black and Blue eleven couldn't gain.
Several times, the punts went far
beyond the region where the receiving back was playing, and twice
these mistakes resulted in touchdowns for Navy.
First blood was drawn early in
the -first quarter when Hopkins lost
the ball On a forward pass to Gillet, which went out of bounds,
although decisions like this were
very difficult to make as the field
was absolutely unmarked and the
position of the side lines had to be
guessed at. Navy then got the ball
on the Hopkins 30-yard line and
started down the field with steady
gains. Dalton got away around
left end for a pretty run of 15
yards, and this put the ball within
easy striking distance. Sowell went
through center on a stimulated run

THE MADISON

P{NNANTS

Dr. Albrecht Kossel Lectures.

, Dr. Albrecht Kossel, director of
the Physiological Institute at the
University of Heidelberg, and winner of the Nobel Medical Research
Prize for 1910, delivered a course
of three lectures at the Medical
School last week, on the Herter
Foundation. His subject was "The
Protein Metabolism."
Professor Kossel, who is one of
the pioneers in the study of biochemistry, or the science of chemistry as applied to biology, is a peculiarly happy selection for the Herter
lectureship, the purpose of which
is "to promote a more intimate
knowledge of the researches of foreign investigators in the field of
medical science."
He is himself said to be the discoverer or seven or eight of the
fifty or more known chemical constituents of cellular life.
Dr. Kossel arrived in this country August 21, and will sail for
Germany October 24. He delivered
the Herter lectures on the afternoons of Wednesday,Thursday, and
Friday of last week. ,

THE NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 9, 1911.
NEW COACH FOR VARSITY
Bob Folwell, Ex-Captain of Penn and
Late Coach of Lafayette
to Help Lynn.

N() small share of the credit of
the Johns Hopkins' showing against
the Navy Saturday is to be attributed to the work during the past
week of Bob Folwell, who has come
to be assistant coach to Head Coach
Lynn during a part, at least, of the
present season. Folwell has been
working hard during the past week
to get the men in shape in the short
time that they have had to prepare
for so difficult a game as the one
against the Navy, but the fact that
a football man of national fame was
present here on the job was kept
a secret, as it was desired not to let
the ,Navy know the local boys were
getting the advantage of his coaching.
,Folwell is a raw-boned, muscular
man of slightly more than medium
height, with high cheek bones and
a commanding voice which penetrates to every part of the field.
This tousle-headed, earnest-minded
man, who rarely ever smiles and
from whom the few words of encouragement are like pearls of precious price to the anxious players,
was for three years left halfback of
pile of the greatest of the University of Pennsylvania's football teams
and for the past two years coach
of the Lafayette College. •
With Folwell coaching is a matter of serious business, and when
he is on the field there is nothing
. more important in the affairs of the
• nation to his vision than the drilling of the boys before him. Personalities count for nothing with
this clear-eyed general, and all candidates fall alike under the ban of
Ills criticism or his sparsely bestowed
words of praise. Every suggestion

he makes is a command in a voice
which means obey or leave the field
at once, and he wastes no time in
persuading the reluctant or obstinate. But there is.withal nothing
that is ordered that the commander
ever hesitates to explain and demonstrate by his own work, and he
will jump in and take part in the
play whenever he sees that it is
necessary to illustrate how such a
play should be properly made.
Folwell was mentioned several
times as a runner-up for the AllAmerican eleven, but he never quite
got there. He was never known
as a spectacular player and his name
was not mentioned half as much
as lots of other men on the Penn
team, but all who knew him as a
player are ready to say that there
was never a player who could be
relied upon more than Bob Folwell.
He was never wanting in a crisis,
he never lost his head nor dropped
the ball, he was not afraid of any
player living, and he could always
be depended upon to stop an opposing player who was coming with
the ball. He was what is known
as a conscientious player, and he
never shirked work to perfect himself as nearly as possible in all the
points of the game. It was a serious business with him, and everyone knew that the hard-muscled
country boy would never do less
than his very best.

Y. M. C. A. Reception.

For a few hours last Friday night
at the Y. M. C. A. reception the
freshmen forgot that they were
freshmen. At least, listening to the
splendid speeches and delving into
the good things provided, they forgot all their troubles and thought
only of the glories of bein(i freshmen at the Johns Hopkins6University.

The president of the Y. M. C. A.
delivered the opening address. Professor Ames then impressed on the
freshmen the fact that an A. B. is
not all one should get from a college course. Dean Griffin emphatically endorsed what Dr. Ames had
said. Next Fulton, like a general
going to battle, inspired the freshmen t'by telling them of the glorious
deeds done last year by football
warriors.
Next Ray spoke in behalf of the
Glee and the Instrumental Clubs. Ray
was followed by Rogers, who, after
noting the great men who had been
editors of college papers, exhorted
every freshman to try to get on
THE NEWS-LETTER staff. Meanwhile everybody had developed enormous appetites, so Holmes' announcement that refreshments would
he served was well received.

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG

High Honor for Black and Blue Prodigies What"Sonny" Mahon
Told Them.

A Column in Which the Correspondents

A party consisting of Taylor
Starck, A. B.,
; 0. K. Schmied,
'13; G. Y. Rusk, '13; J. E. Uhler,
'13; Roland Gminder,'13, and J. S.
Dickinson, '13, made a walking trip
to Frederick and Hagerstown during the week of September 18.
At Ridgeville, a little hamlet on the
border-line between Carroll and
Frederick counties, where the party
stopped for supper their first day
out from Baltimore, they met with
an interesting experience.
As they sat, dusty and dishevelled, on the porch of the Eagle
Hotel, inhaling the tempting aroma
of a Maryland country supper, a big
Welch touring car drew up before
the hostelry, and by the eagerness
with which the hotel's hostess ran
out to greet the newcomers and the
effusiveness with which she welcomed them, the Hopkins group
judged them to be persons of some
importance in that part of the
country.
The greetings over, the principal
personage of the new arrivals, a
"dead game sport" with a golf
cap set on one side of his head
and a cigar stump clenched between
his teeth, strutted over to the dusty
pedestrians and, twinkling his
thumbs in his armholes, "sized them
up."
"So boys, where you goin'? Hagerstown? What, walkin'? Wanta
ride? Give you a ride if you vote
for Gorman—vote for Gorman ?"
"Hurrah for Gorman !" shouted
the party in merry sport. "Martin,"
called the politician to his chauffeur,
"you just take these young gents
anywhere they wanta go," and, with
sorrow be it related, two of the
company leaped up, accepted the
offer without more words, and deserting their brethern, were whisked
on toward their destination in the
comfortable tonneau of a luxurious
car.
"Where you from, boys?" inquired the sport of those who were
left. "Hopkins? Johns Hopkins?
Great institution that; tell you truth,
I think Johns Hopkins greatest institution in the whole world, ain't
it? Old Man Remsen's connected
with that institution, ain't he?
President? Oh, yes—fine old chap—
met him out onct. 'This Sonny
Mahon, ain't it?' sez he. That's what
they call me, sez I—fine old chap.
Done Hopkins a good turn myself
onct—owned a piece of ground
down there on Pratt street they
had to have—might a-squeezed
ten thousand dollars out of 'em—

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 9, 1911
The News-Letter and What It
Stands For.

With this issue, the first of the
session, THE NEWS-LETTER begins
its sixteenth year of existence, and
at this time it may not be inappropriate to outline briefly the plans
which have been made for the corning year and to state again the reasons for publishing a student weekly at Johns Hopkins.
Until two years ago, THE NEwsLETTER was a bi-weekly publication
of uncertain time, character, and
appearance. It was decided then
by the Board of Editors that the
needs of the University, student
body and alumni, was not for a depository of out-of-date news, and
pseudo literary contributions which
were not fit to find a resting place
elsewhere. The editors thought
that a real, live newspaper, appearing on time, containing items of
interest about past happenings, adequately forecasting those which
were to come, and providing a forurn for the discussion of questions of
interest to those connected with the
University, was what was needed,
and so THE NMS-LETTER started to
make its appearance, in a new form,
on the Monday of each week.
That this change was for the best
has been abundantly demonstrated
by the way the paper has been supported. Its circulation has increased
800 per cent.; the advertising revenue has been more than tripled, and
letters of commendation have come
from all parts of the country. For
this year it is proposed to conduct
THE NEWS-LETTER along these same
lines which have proven so successful. Some innovations will be made,
but nothing radical is contemplated.

We will try to be conservative, not
yellow.
Yet it is the aim of the editors
not to be too conservative and Se(late. From time to time, new humorous features will be introduced;
the news of familiar happenings will
be reduced to a minimum, and most
of the space will be devoted to a
discussion of those questions which
are unfamiliar, or at least not hackneyed. All of the accounts will be
colored in such a way that a pleasant hour reading THE NEWS-LETTER
will be furnished weekly to all the
subscribers.
A publication such as this one,
is not issued for the exploitation of
the literary ability of those who
may happen to be the editors. It
is issued because, if conducted
rightly, it can be of real service to
the University, her alumni, faculty,
and students. And to be of service
will be the constant aim of THE
NEws-LETTER. We, the editors,
want to make it worthy of the Johns
Hopkins University; we want to
cultivate a stronger feeling of loyalty among the students. We want
to make the relations between the
faculty and the students, and between the alumni and the University,
closer and more pleasant. We want
THE NEWS-LETTER to help in every
phase of life at Johns Hopkins.
We ask your hearty co-operation.

the University of Virginia, and Gettysburg Ccalege are the three important additions to this season's
schedule.
Navy not only had one of the
strongest elevens in the country last
year, but the team went through
the entire season without being
scored on. Virginia won its opening game by the phenomenal score
of 81 to o. This clearly proves that
the Charlottesville boys are living
up to their past reputations as crack
football players. Gettysburg, while
not so well known as Navy and
Virginia, is, nevertheless, a very
strong team. The University of
Pennsylvania had a very hard time
defeating the Gettysburg 'eleven a
week ago and only nosed out a
victory by the close score of 5 to 3.
As can be seen from the accompanying schedule, all the games
except that with Navy last Saturday, and the one with Stevens on
the coming Saturday, will be played,
at Homewood. This will give Hopkins students and Hopkins supporters seven weeks of uninter7,
rupted football at home which,from
the progress made so far, is certain
to be of a higher quality than any
ever played at Homewood heretofore.
. Big crowds are expected at all
the home games. The Hopkins
teams are rapidly gaining favor
among the Baltimore lovers of
sport, and the attendance is becoming larger each season. Certain
seats will be reserved only at the
University of Virginia, St. John's
and Carlisle Indian games, and the
extra charge will be but twenty-five
cents instead of fifty cents as heretofore. A general admission ticket
is all that is required for any seats
in the grandstands at the other
games.

W. N. C.—Please tell me what Coleridge had in mind when he wrote the
following lines :
"A sadder and a wiser man
He rose the morrow morn."

. A member of the English Department has made the following
suggestion:
"I have always maintained in my
lectures that Coleridge was a good
bit of a prophet. I am of the
opinion, therefore, that he had in
mind the *plight, in which those
youths, with Physics deficiencies,
find themselves."
Infant of 1915—I am a freshman, and
want to know whether to wear white
gloves to Hopkins functions. Can
"Gassy Gus" enlighten me?

Gloves are not necessary, but
trousers are.
Freshman—May first-year men use
the library?

For all freshmen the library reading room forms a place of innocent
amusement. There they can chat with
each other; take their bottles without fear of interruption; ogle the
library assistants; read the Police
Gazette; match pennies; search
with a misapplied diligence for
mono-syllabic translations of Rabelais, Bocaccio and Maupassant, and
prepare, with many lively chorusings, their lessons for the morrow.
For all of these things the freshmen
use the library. At least they have
in the past.
Once more "Aprille" is with us,
and the "veynes" are being "bathed
in licour" again, although in common parlance, the month is October,
and to vulgar eyes the trees don't
seem to be-getting any new leaves.
Can't the Prestonized School Board
be called in to prevent the propagation of such absurdities?

brick, and resembles in architecture
the Carroll Mansion. The laboratory and greenhouse (which adjoins) have already been outgrown,
and workmen have been engaged
the whole summer in building an
addition,consisting of another building and greenhouse, the same size
as the older ones.
In front of the laboratory is the
botanical garden, which probably
comparatively few Hopkins students have seen, although it is several years old. A trip to the garden
quite repays one, for here, surrounding a fountain, are well-kept
paths and lawns, between which arc
beds full of various plants, well arranged and fully classified.
Take next the little path running northwestward through a
woods, and then—ah! (this thought
has been saved for the last) then,
there bursts forth upon the startled
gaze the Hopkins swimming pool!
It is not a secret. Why, as early
as last spring everybody knew about
it. The papers came out in half
columns "on reliable authority,"
about the new sport Hopkins would
indulge in. Some of the facetious
ones even began suggesting that
Sol Silberman and Buck Schreiber
begin to get in training for an
aquatic duel.
But let me break it to you gently
—"somebody blundered, it is only
a frog pond !"
Still there it nestles, with a big
concrete retaining wall to hold in
the waters, and every night along
its banks countless frogs croak
away to their hearts content; for
Mr. Johnstone, the watchman, says
that "several doctors emptied tadpotes there and they certainly
throve prodigiously."
The improvements chronicled
above are all the summer has
brought us, and the new Hopkins
would seem but little nearer than
a year ago, had we not the promise
from President Remsen, the class
of 1915 will graduate in new halls.
